questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
An engineer must configure HSPR protocol on two Cisco Nexus 9000 Series Switches running a virtual port channel. In addition, the HSRP implementation must meet these requirements:
✑ It must allow more than 500 groups.
✑ switch1 must act as the primary switch.
✑ Both switches must use a user-defined hardware address.
Drag and drop the commands from the right to complete a configuration of the HSRP on the left. The commands are used more than once. Not all commands are used.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content: yup solution is correct

questions.question_text:
An engineer must configure OSPFv2 connectivity between a pair of Cisco Nexus switches. The connection between the switches must meet these requirements:
✑ Use unicast for updates.
✑ Use decentralized communication of updates.
✑ Full adjacency between switches.
Which configuration is needed to meet these requirements?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
D is wrong as p2p uses multicast

Selected Answer: D
I'm not certain if D is the correct answer, but it's the one I selected. I excluded virtual links because they are primarily used in exceptional cases where a direct connection to area 0 isn't feasible, and their use is generally discouraged when a direct connection is possible. In this context, I don't believe C is the correct answer, even though D might not be entirely accurate either.

Selected Answer: D
P2P is correct. OSPF Point to Point Network Key points:-
- OSPF P2P network type is Default on T1, DS-3, and SONET links and on frame-relay point-to-point sub-interfaces.
- There is no DR/BDR election.
- Uses the multicast destination to AllSPFRouters (224.0.0.5), except for retransmitted LSAs, which are sent as unicast.
- The IP of the advertising router is the next-hop IP.
- On point-to-point links, OSPF doesn’t care if the subnet mask doesn’t match.
- The hello interval is 10 seconds, and the dead interval is 40 seconds.
The LSAs are updates, so in P2P they are unicast.
https://afrozahmad.com/blog/ospf-network-types-explained/

Selected Answer: C
The destination address of OSPF packets on Point to Point networks will always be 224.0.0.5(a multicast address)

Selected Answer: D
D is correct,P2P is correct

Selected Answer: D
P2P is correct
The answer is ** C **

comments.content: Sorry only retransmitted LSAs are unicast in P2P.so C looks correct.

discussion.content: Although P2P Ospf uses multicast , it’s updates are unicast! Hence D is correct.

Selected Answer: C
Answer is C. D is wrong because p2p links use multicast for updates, virtual links use unicast for updates.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

A Virtual Link is an OSPF tunnel, a multi-hop point-to-point unicast adjacency; 
it is, in essence, an extension of Area 0 across (transit area) another area.

I choose the C
https://community.cisco.com/t5/routing/unicast-ospf-messages-send-by-the-dr-bdr/td-p/4424186
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/open-shortest-path-first-ospf/47866-ospfdb7.html
i'll go with C (virtual link). If the switches are connected back to back i would use p2p, but it does not guaranty unicast updates, the only option (in the exercise) it does is virtual links.

Selected Answer: D
The correct one is D - a point to point network in ospf: A network that exists only between two routers. All neighbors on a point-to-point network establish adjacency, and there is no DR required.

choices.D: interface with a type of p2p network

questions.question_text: An infrastructure architect is analyzing the deployment type for an application. Several companies must be able to operate the application environment and integrate it with a third-party protocol. The development team also must have maximum control over their development environment, including the operating system used, Python interpreter, and corresponding libraries. Which cloud deployment solution meets these requirements?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
another wrong one, its D, you need even control on OS, so it cant be SaaS...

must be infra.. so D is the correct one..

IaaS - Control everything (VM resources, OS and app like cPanel)
PasS - Control just the cPanel app for exemple (like the app that is installed in the vm for example)
SaaS - Only consume the service that the app gives (for example a dashboard app... that is hosted in the cPanel :D)

Selected Answer: D
Agreed, in SaaS you can't control the OS. Correct answer is D, IaaS.

Selected Answer: D
Community cloud, IaaS so you can control the OS.

choices.A: private cloud Platform as a Service
choices.C: hybrid cloud Software as a Service
choices.B: public cloud Storage as a Service
choices.D: community cloud Infrastructure as a Service

discussion.content: The answer is A, because the question states that the Remote site is connected to the Hub site via an ASBR router. Hence, an ASBR router redistributes a non OSPF or an External route into the NSSA area which is a Type 7. There is no ABR router in the question.

If you interpret "sent to the remote office OSPF area" as going from ABR to this NSSA ospf area, then it is type 3. But if you interpret "sent to the remote office OSPF area" as the NSSA ASBR sending to the OSPF area -- then the external route will be sent in to the NSSA ospf area as Type 7. Who knows what Cisco means to say but the wording of that implies "direction" is vague to me.

Selected Answer: A
The answer is A- lsa type 7

if an ASBR exists within the NSSA, that ASBR will create lsa type 7
it should be D, type 7 is translated into type 5 at ABR and then sent towards backbone, not towards NSSA

comments.content: you are perfectly right! It asks you about which LSA is sent towards the Remote Office, not inversely! Answer is D
Type 5 LSA doesn't come out from AREA 0, only type 7 LSA are released from AREA 0

questions.question_text:
A small remote office is set to connect to the regional hub site via NSSA ASBR.
Which type of LSA is sent to the remote office OSPF area?
questions.answer_description: The remote site is connected to the Hub site via an ASBR router. Hence, an ASBR router redistributes a non OSPF or an External route into the NSSA area which is a Type 7. There is no ABR router in the question.
